company.name: Residual Pumpkin Entity, LLC
company.business_description: Residual Pumpkin Entity, LLC (formerly CafePress) developed and operated an e-commerce platform at www.cafepress.com that allows consumers to purchase customized merchandise such as t-shirts and coffee mugs from other consumers or shopkeepers on the platform. The company collected personal information from both consumers and shopkeepers.

complaint.factual_background: CafePress, an online marketplace for customized merchandise, failed to implement reasonable data security measures to protect consumer personal information including names, email addresses, Social Security numbers, and payment card data. In February 2019, a hacker exploited multiple security vulnerabilities and stole personal information of millions of consumers, including over 180,000 unencrypted Social Security numbers. The company delayed notifying consumers for months and continued to leave accounts vulnerable even after resetting passwords.

representations_made.description: Claimed to implement reasonable security measures including encryption, firewalls, limited access and other controls to protect personal information
representations_made.quoted_text: We do our best to provide you with a safe and convenient shopping experience. Our Websites incorporate physical, technical, and administrative safeguards to protect the confidentiality of the information we collect through the Websites, including the use of encryption, firewalls, limited access and other controls where appropriate.

representations_made.description: Pledged to use the best and most accepted methods and technologies to ensure personal information is safe and secure
representations_made.quoted_text: CafePress.com also pledges to use the best and most accepted methods and technologies to insure [sic] your personal information is safe and secure.

representations_made.description: Guaranteed safe and secure shopping on checkout pages
Claimed that servers are secure and personal information is stored safely
representations_made.quoted_text: Please note our servers are secure and your personal information is stored safely in our system.

representations_made.description: Represented that they took appropriate steps to secure consumer account information following security incidents
representations_made.quoted_text: Residual Pumpkin told individuals, law enforcement, and regulators that the April 15, 2019 password reset effectively blocked the passwords from subsequent unauthorized use.

representations_made.description: Represented that email addresses would only be used for order notifications and receipt
representations_made.quoted_text: Email address for order notifications and receipt.

representations_made.description: Represented compliance with EU-U.S. and Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield Framework principles
representations_made.quoted_text: CafePress Inc. complies with the EU-US Privacy Shield Framework and the Swiss-US Privacy Shield Framework as set forth by the US Department of Commerce regarding the collection, use, and retention of personal information from European Union member countries and Switzerland transferred to the United States pursuant to Privacy Shield. CafePress has certified that it adheres to the Privacy Shield Principles with respect to such data.

representations_made.description: Promised to honor data erasure requests from EEA and Switzerland residents
representations_made.quoted_text: The right to request data erasure: You have the right to have your data erased from our Websites if the data is no longer necessary for the purpose for which it was collected, you withdraw consent and no other legal basis for processing exists, or you believe your fundamental rights to data privacy and protection outweigh our legitimate interest in continuing the processing.

counts.title: Data Security Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Respondents represented that they implemented reasonable measures to protect Personal Information against unauthorized access
counts.fact: Respondents did not implement reasonable measures to protect Personal Information against unauthorized access, including failing to protect against SQL injection attacks, storing Social Security numbers in clear text, using deprecated encryption algorithms, failing to implement patch management, allowing weak passwords, and failing to implement reasonable incident response procedures
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 50 is false or misleading.

counts.title: Response to Data Security Incident Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Respondents represented that they took appropriate steps to secure consumer account information following security incidents
counts.fact: Respondents had not taken appropriate steps to secure access to consumer accounts following security incidents. Consumer accounts remained at risk even after the passwords had been reset because anyone with access to the breached data could take over another user's account through password resets using security questions
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 52 is false or misleading.

counts.title: Unfair Data Security Practices
counts.representation: Respondents failed to employ reasonable data security measures to protect Personal Information
counts.fact: This failure caused or is likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that is not outweighed by countervailing benefits to consumers or competition and is not reasonably avoidable by consumers themselves
counts.conclusion: This practice is an unfair act or practice.

counts.title: Data Collection and Use Misrepresentation
counts.representation: Respondents represented that they would use email addresses only for order notification and receipt
counts.fact: Respondents did not use email addresses only for order notification and receipt. Respondents sent marketing emails to consumers irrespective of whether they consented to receive such emails
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 55 is false or misleading.

counts.title: Misrepresentation Relating to Privacy Shield Frameworks
counts.representation: Respondents represented that they adhered to the EU-U.S. and the Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield frameworks, including the principles of Choice, Security, and Access
counts.fact: Respondents did not adhere to the Privacy Shield Principles of Choice, Security, and Access
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 57 is false or misleading.

counts.title: Misrepresentation Relating to Deletion of Consumer Data
counts.representation: Respondents represented that they honored requests from residents of the EEA and Switzerland to erase data and restrict the use of personal data for direct marketing
counts.fact: Respondents did not honor requests from residents of the EEA and Switzerland to erase data and restrict the use of personal data for direct marketing. Until November 2019, Residual Pumpkin only deactivated user accounts when it received such requests but did not delete the associated account information
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 59 is false or misleading.

counts.title: Unfair Withholding of Payable Commissions After Security Breach
counts.representation: Respondents withheld payable commissions owed to shopkeepers whose accounts were closed after a security breach
counts.fact: Withholding payable commissions owed to shopkeepers whose accounts were closed after a security breach is likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that is not outweighed by countervailing benefits to consumers or competition and is not reasonably avoidable by consumers themselves
counts.conclusion: This practice is an unfair act or practice.

definitions.Covered Incident: any instance in which any United States federal, state, or local law or regulation requires Respondent to notify any U.S. federal, state, or local government entity that information collected or received, directly or indirectly, by Respondent from or about an individual consumer was, or is reasonably believed to have been, accessed or acquired without authorization.
definitions.Personal Information: individually identifiable information from or about an individual consumer, including: (1) a first and last name; (2) a physical address; (3) an email address or other online contact information, such as an instant messaging user identifier or a screen name; (4) a telephone number; (5) date of birth; (6) a Social Security number; (7) driver's license or other government issued identification number; (8)financial institution account number; (9) credit or debit card information; (10) a persistent identifier, such as a customer number held in a "cookie," a static Internet Protocol ("IP") address, a mobile device ID, or processor serial number; and (11) authentication credentials such as a user ID, password, and security questions and answers. For purposes of this definition, "consumer" includes any individual who is, or seeks to become, an employee, officer, or independent contractor of Respondent.
definitions.Respondent: Residual Pumpkin Entity, LLC, a limited liability company, formerly doing business as CafePress and its successors and assigns.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent its privacy and security measures, participation in privacy programs, privacy choices, deletion practices, or protection of Personal Information.

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent privacy and security measures to prevent unauthorized access to Personal Information
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent's privacy and security measures to prevent unauthorized access to Personal Information

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent membership, adherence, compliance, certification, or participation in privacy or security programs
requirements.quoted_text: The extent to which Respondent is a member of, adheres to, complies with, is certified by, is endorsed by, or otherwise participates in any privacy or security program sponsored by a government or any self-regulatory or standard-setting organization

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent privacy and security measures to honor privacy choices exercised by users
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent's privacy and security measures to honor the privacy choices exercised by users

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent information deletion and retention practices
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent's information deletion and retention practices

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent the extent to which Respondent protects privacy, security, availability, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information
requirements.quoted_text: The extent to which Respondent otherwise protects the privacy, security, availability, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program that protects Personal Information, including documentation, risk assessments, safeguards, testing, service provider management, and program evaluation.

requirements.description: Establish and implement comprehensive information security program within 60 days
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent, and any business that Respondent controls directly, or indirectly, in connection with the collection, maintenance, use, or disclosure of, or provision of access to, Personal Information, must, within sixty (60) days of issuance of this order, establish and implement, and thereafter maintain, a comprehensive information security program ("Information Security Program") that protects the privacy, security, confidentiality, and integrity of such Personal Information.

requirements.description: Document in writing the content, implementation, and maintenance of the Information Security Program
requirements.quoted_text: Document in writing the content, implementation, and maintenance of the Information Security Program

requirements.description: Provide written program and evaluations to board or senior officer at least once every 12 months and within 30 days after a Covered Incident
requirements.quoted_text: Provide the written program and any evaluations thereof or updates thereto to Respondent's board of directors or governing body or, if no such board or equivalent governing body exists, to a senior officer of Respondent responsible for Respondent's Information Security Program at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly (not to exceed thirty (30) days) after a Covered Incident

requirements.description: Designate a qualified employee or employees to coordinate and be responsible for the Information Security Program
requirements.quoted_text: Designate a qualified employee or employees to coordinate and be responsible for the Information Security Program

requirements.description: Assess and document risks at least once every 12 months and within 30 days following a Covered Incident
requirements.quoted_text: Assess and document, at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly (not to exceed thirty (30) days) following a Covered Incident, internal and external risks to the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information that could result in the (1) unauthorized collection, maintenance, use, or disclosure of, or provision of access to, Personal Information; or the (2) misuse, loss, theft, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information

requirements.description: Design, implement, maintain, and document safeguards including technical monitoring, vulnerability review, data minimization, encryption, access controls, device security, multi-factor authentication, and employee training
requirements.quoted_text: Design, implement, maintain, and document safeguards that control for the internal and external risks Respondent identifies to the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information identified in response to sub-Provision II.D. Each safeguard must be based on the volume and sensitivity of the Personal Information that is at risk, and the likelihood that the risk could be realized and result in the (1) unauthorized collection, maintenance, use, or disclosure of, or provision of access to, Personal Information; or the (2) misuse, loss, theft, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information.

requirements.description: Assess sufficiency of safeguards at least once every 12 months and within 30 days following a Covered Incident
requirements.quoted_text: Assess, at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly (not to exceed thirty (30) days) following a Covered Incident, the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to address the internal and external risks to the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information, and modify the Information Security Program based on the results

requirements.description: Test and monitor effectiveness of safeguards at least once every 12 months and within 30 days following a Covered Incident, including vulnerability testing every 4 months and penetration testing annually
requirements.quoted_text: Test and monitor the effectiveness of the safeguards at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly (not to exceed 30 days) following a Covered Incident, and modify the Information Security Program based on the results. Such testing and monitoring must include vulnerability testing of Respondent's network(s) once every four months and promptly (not to exceed 30 days) after a Covered Incident, and penetration testing of Respondent's network(s) at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly (not to exceed 30 days) after a Covered Incident

requirements.description: Select and retain service providers capable of safeguarding Personal Information and contractually require them to implement safeguards
requirements.quoted_text: Select and retain service providers capable of safeguarding Personal Information they access through or receive from Respondent, and contractually require service providers to implement and maintain safeguards sufficient to address the internal and external risks to the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information

requirements.description: Consult with and seek guidance from independent third-party experts on data protection and privacy
requirements.quoted_text: Consult with, and seek appropriate guidance from, independent, third-party experts on data protection and privacy in the course of establishing, implementing, maintaining, and updating the Information Security Program

requirements.description: Evaluate and adjust the Information Security Program at least once every 12 months and based on changes in operations, Covered Incidents, or new methods
requirements.quoted_text: Evaluate and adjust the Information Security Program in light of any changes to Respondent's operations or business arrangements, a Covered Incident, new or more efficient technological or operational methods to control for the risks identified in Provision II.D of this Order, or any other circumstances that Respondent knows or has reason to know may have an impact on the effectiveness of the Information Security Program or any of its individual safeguards. At a minimum, Respondent must evaluate the Information Security Program at least once every twelve (12) months and modify the Information Security Program based on the results.

provisions.title: Independent Program Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of the Information Security Program for 20 years, with the initial assessment covering the first 180 days.

requirements.description: Obtain assessments from qualified, objective, independent third-party professionals using accepted procedures and standards
requirements.quoted_text: The Assessments must be obtained from one or more qualified, objective, independent third-party professionals ("Assessors"), who: (1) use procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession; (2) conduct an independent review of the Information Security Program; (3) retain all documents relevant to each Assessment for five (5) years after completion of such Assessment, and (4) will provide such documents to the Commission within ten (10) days of receipt of a written request from a representative of the Commission.

requirements.description: Provide the Associate Director for Enforcement with the name, affiliation, and qualifications of the proposed Assessor for approval
requirements.quoted_text: For each Assessment, Respondent must provide the Associate Director for Enforcement for the Bureau of Consumer Protection at the Federal Trade Commission with the name, affiliation, and qualifications of the proposed Assessor, whom the Associate Director shall have the authority to approve in her or his sole discretion.

requirements.description: Obtain initial assessment covering first 180 days and biennial assessments thereafter for 20 years
requirements.quoted_text: The reporting period for the Assessments must cover: (1) the first 180 days after the issuance date of the Order for the initial Assessment; and (2) each 2-year period thereafter for twenty (20) years after issuance of the Order for the biennial Assessmen ts.

requirements.description: Each assessment must determine implementation, assess effectiveness, identify gaps, address prior gaps, and identify supporting evidence
requirements.quoted_text: Each Assessment must, for the entire assessment period: (1) determine whether Respondent has implemented and maintained the Information Security Program required by Provision II of this Order, titled Mandated Information Security Program; (2) assess the effectiveness of Respondent's implementation and maintenance of sub-Provisions II.A-J; (3) identify any gaps or weaknesses in, or instances of material noncompliance with, the Information Security Program; (4) address the status of gaps or weaknesses in, or instances of material non-compliance with, the Information Security Program that were identified in any prior Assessment required by this Order; and (5) ident ify specific evidence (including documents reviewed, sampling and testing performed, and interviews conducted) examined to make such determinations, assessments, and identifications

requirements.description: Complete each assessment within 60 days after the end of the reporting period and submit initial assessment to Commission within 10 days
requirements.quoted_text: Each Assessment must be completed within sixty (60) days after the end of the reporting period to which the Assessment applies. Unless otherwise directed by a Commission representative in writing, Respondent must submit an unredacted copy of the initial Assessment and a proposed redacted copy suitable for public disclosure of the initial Assessment to the Commission within ten (10) days after the Assessment has been completed

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide all relevant information and materials to the Assessor, make network and IT assets available, and disclose all material facts without misrepresentation.

requirements.description: Provide or make available to the Assessor all relevant information and material for which there is no reasonable claim of privilege
requirements.quoted_text: Provide or otherwise make available to the Assessor all information and material in its possession, custody, or control that is relevant to the Assessment for which there is no reasonable claim of privilege.

requirements.description: Provide information about networks and IT assets and visibility to portions deemed in scope
requirements.quoted_text: Provide or otherwise make available to the Assessor information about Respondent's network(s) and all of Respondent's IT assets so that the Assessor can determine the scope of the Assessment, and visibility to those portions of the network(s) and IT assets deemed in scope

requirements.description: Disclose all material facts to the Assessor and not misrepresent any fact material to the Assessment
requirements.quoted_text: Disclose all material facts to the Assessor, and not misrepresent in any manner, expressly or by implication, any fact material to the Assessor's: (1) determination of whether Respondent has implemented and maintained the Information Security Program required by Provision II of this Order, titled Mandated Information Security Program; (2) assessment of the effectiveness of the implementation and maintenance of sub-Provisions II.A-J; or (3) identification of any gaps or weaknesses in, or instances of material noncompliance with, the Information Security Program.

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide annual certifications from a senior corporate manager or officer confirming establishment, implementation, and maintenance of Order requirements and disclosing material noncompliance or Covered Incidents.

requirements.description: Provide annual certification one year after issuance and each year thereafter confirming compliance and disclosing Covered Incidents
requirements.quoted_text: One year after the issuance date of this Order, and each year thereafter, provide the Commission with a certification from a senior corporate manager, or, if no such senior corporate manager exists, a senior officer of Respondent responsible for Respondent's Information Security Program that: (1) Respondent has established, implemented, and maintained the requirements of this Order; (2) Respondent is not aware of any material noncompliance that has not been (a) corrected or (b) disclosed to the Commission; and (3)includes a brief description of all Covered Incidents during the certified period.

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a report to the Commission within 30 days of discovering a Covered Incident, including date, facts, information types, number of consumers, remediation acts, and representative notices.

requirements.description: Submit Covered Incident report to Commission within 30 days of discovery
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Respondent, within thirty (30) days after Respondent's discovery of a Covered Incident, must submit a report to the Commission.

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Respondent must pay $500,000 to the Commission within 8 days of the effective date of the Order.

requirements.description: Pay $500,000 to the Commission held in escrow
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent must pay to the Commission $500,000 which Respondent stipulates their undersigned counsel holds in escrow for no purpose other than payment to the Commission.

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Respondent relinquishes rights to transferred assets, and facts in the Complaint establish elements for bankruptcy nondischargeability and may be used for consumer redress or other relief.

requirements.description: Relinquish dominion and all legal and equitable right, title, and interest in all assets transferred pursuant to this Order
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent relinquishes dominion and all legal and equitable right, title, and interest in all assets transferred pursuant to this Order and may not seek the return of any assets.

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide sufficient customer information to enable the Commission to administer consumer redress to shopkeepers who did not receive payable commissions.

requirements.description: Provide customer information for consumer redress within 14 days of Commission request
requirements.quoted_text: If a representative of the Commission requests in writing any information related to redress, Respondent must provide it, in the form prescribed by the Commission representative, within 14 days.

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit acknowledgment of receipt to the Commission within 10 days, deliver Order to personnel and obtain signed acknowledgments within specified timeframes for 10 years.

requirements.description: Submit acknowledgment of receipt to Commission within 10 days after effective date
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent, within 10 days after the effective date of this Order, must submit to the Commission an acknowledgment of receipt of this Order sworn under penalty of perjury.

requirements.description: Deliver copy of Order to all principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, and agents with specified responsibilities for 10 years
requirements.quoted_text: For 10 years after the issuance date of this Order, Respondent must deliver a copy of this Order to: (1) all principals, officers, directors, and LLC managers and members; (2) all employees having managerial responsibilities for conduct related to the subject matter of the Order and all agents and representatives with managerial or professional responsibilities for conduct related to the subject matter of the Order; and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure as set forth in the Provision titled Compliance Reports and Notices. Delivery must occur within 10 days after the effective date of this Order for current personnel. For all others, delivery must occur before they assume their responsibilities.

requirements.description: Obtain signed and dated acknowledgment from each individual or entity within 30 days
requirements.quoted_text: From each individual or entity to which Respondent delivered a copy of this Order, Respondent mustobtain, within 30 days, a signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt of this Order.

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit compliance reports one year after issuance and provide compliance notices within 14 days of changes in structure, contact information, or bankruptcy filings.

requirements.description: Submit compliance report one year after issuance date sworn under penalty of perjury
requirements.quoted_text: One year after the issuance date of this Order, Respondent must submit a compliance report, sworn under penalty of perjury

requirements.description: Submit compliance notice within 14 days of changes in designated point of contact or entity structure
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent must submit a compliance notice, sworn under penalty of perjury, within 14 days of any change in: (a) any designated point of contact; or (b) the structure of Respondent or any entity that Respondent has any ownership interest in or controls directly or indirectly that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Order

requirements.description: Submit notice of bankruptcy filing within 14 days
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent must submit notice of the filing of any bankruptcy petition, insolvency proceeding, or similar proceeding by or against such Respondent within 14 days of its filing.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain specified records for 20 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, marketing materials, assessments, and compliance documentation.

requirements.description: Create certain records for 20 years after issuance date and retain each record for 5 years
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Respondent must create certain records for 20 years after the issuance date of the Order, and retain each such record for 5 years.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Commission representatives may request compliance reports, produce records, interview personnel, and use lawful means including posing as consumers to monitor compliance.

requirements.description: Submit additional compliance reports or information within 10 days of written request from Commission representative
requirements.quoted_text: Within 10 days of receipt of a written request from a representative of the Commission, Respondent must: submit additional compliance reports or other requested information, which must be sworn under penalty of perjury, and produce records for inspection and copying.

requirements.description: Permit Commission representatives to communicate directly with Respondent and interview affiliated persons
requirements.quoted_text: For matters concerning this Order, representatives of the Commission are authorized to communicate directly with Respondent. Respondent must permit representatives of the Commission to interview anyone affiliated with Respondent who has agreed to such an interview.

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is final and effective upon publication and will terminate 20 years from issuance or from the most recent date a complaint is filed alleging violation, whichever is later.

requirements.description: Order is final and effective upon publication on Commission website
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Order is final and effective upon the date of its publication on the Commission's website (ftc.gov) as a final order.

duration.termination_text: This Order will terminate 20 years from the date of its issuance (which date may be stated at the end of this Order, near the Commission's seal), or 20 years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying settlement) in federal court alleging any violation of this Order, whichever comes later
